Award.AwardTitle: Controllable Polariton Patterns: An Approach to Low-Energy All-Optical Communication Devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on the understanding of physics required to implement a new concept for optical communication systems with ultralow energy costs. This involves the understanding and use of novel type of physical pattern, called a polariton, which is a pattern of light and electrical energy bound together and is capable of moving through small tubes and cavities in semiconductor chips. Better understanding and use of polaritons is still a great challenge to understand and predict how they will behave. This project will bring together three disciplines of basic science/engineering, in order to develop a better and more unified understanding of how polaritons behave for communication application. The project involves a collaboration with France, which will provide experimental tests of the new models, and collaborations on theory with Germany and Hong Kong.

The application of polariton patterns for low-energy optical communication devices will have a significant impact on the overall energy savings in electronic systems. PI intends to write a graduate-student-level text book on nonlinear semiconductor optics, integrate the outcome of his research into the teaching and training of graduate and undergraduate students? course and train them in interdisciplinary research concepts involving semiconductor quantum wells, excitonic interactions, semiconductor microcavities and exicton polaritons. The PI further plans to develop MATLAB codes for use by undergraduate students to simulate holographic optical interconnection maps.

The project will bring together the physics of many-particle correlations in exciton systems (including semiconductor quantum wells and semiconductor microcavities), the physics of pattern formation, the mathematical branch of catastrophe theory and the engineering science of communication devices. It will study the basic physical mechanisms that can lead to pattern formation in polariton systems, in particular generalizations of stationary Turing patterns to polariton quantum fluids. For the initial phase of the project the examples of possible devices include an all-optical switch or transistor and an all-optical controllable fan-out interconnect.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project was to lay the foundation for future use of semiconductor microcavities in optical communication networks. The underlying hope is to find low-energy optical alternatives to current - mostly purely electrical - device designs, even if presently such a search involves completely new design concepts with very low technology readiness levels.

To achieve our main goal, we combined several different disciplines of basic sciences and engineering, namely the physics of many-particle correlations in exciton systems (including semiconductor quantum wells and semiconductor microcavities), the physics of pattern formation, the mathematical branch of catastrophe theory, and the engineering science of communication devices. We performed theoretical studies of the basic physical mechanisms that can lead to pattern formation in polariton systems, as well as ways to control these patterns. An example central to our work was that of a two-spot pattern, in which a pump beam in normal incidence can lead to an instability that creates off-axis emission in two specific off-axis directions. Under certain circumstances, the directions can be changed by another instability if a weak seed beam is applied to that target direction. This switching of emission directions with a weak seed (or control) beam is akin to an all-optical transistor, in the sense that it allows for very large optically-triggered optical gain.

The products generated by this project include software packages and scientific journal publications that contain the insights gained from this work. In particular, the insights related to the intellectual merit of this project include the following. From direct numerical solutions of the relevant equations of motion, we found that the stationary polariton patterns, such as the aforementioned two-spot patterns, depend on a number of parameters, including  the cavity's anisotropy and the intensity of the weak control beam. In order to get a deeper understanding of the pattern control, we developed a population competition model that allowed us to compute non-equilibrium phase diagrams. These phase diagrams helped us gain an intuitive understanding of the origin of numerically observed hysteresis as well as parametric dependence of the switching times and switching energies. For a 60° switching of a two-spot pattern we found that the gain from the switching, defined as the ratio of the switched beam intensity over the control beam intensity, depends sensitively on the pump intensity and reaches approximately 10,000 for a pump intensity that is about 0.5% above the pump threshold intensity for off-axis emission. Similarly, we found the minimum control intensity to be approximately  1/1,000,000 times the pump threshold intensity, and the minimum switching time to be approximately 1 nanosecond.

Our research also provided a detailed understanding of effects related to the polarization of the incident and emitted beams. We were able to predict an all-optical control of the spin/polarization pattern of the emitted beams in the case of the optical spin Hall effect. We predicted that a pump beam that excites a semiconductor double cavity can rotate the far-field spin/polarization pattern of the optical spin Hall effect. The underlying mechanism is that of Coulombic interactions between the polaritons. Our theoretical predictions were verified by our experimental colleagues in France.

We also used our theory to predict four-wave mixing instabilities that involve orbital angular momentum of light/polaritons, in contrast to those involving linear momentum of light/polaritons. Instead of generating two directions (corresponding to two linear momenta in a two-spot pattern), the instabilities can create two different orbital angular momentum states. This establishes a link between two different disciplines of physics: that of orbital angular momentum of light, and that of nonlinear dynamics (here in polaritonic systems).

The broader impact of our work is provided by several factors. For example, the principle investigator edited a book on graphene, and for that book he wrote an introductory tutorial that takes a broader look at the optics of two-dimensional (e.g. graphene) and quasi-two dimensional (e.g. GaAs quantum wells) systems. The project also supported the PI's ongoing work on a monograph on many-particle physics semiconductor optics. During the project, the PI also engaged in outreach activities that involved the Tohono O'odham Community College (TOCC) in Sells, Arizona, which is a college that serves mainly the Native Americans. While the topic of pattern formation in polaritonic quantum fluids was not suitable for K-14 education, a formally related topic, namely population dynamics in ecological systems, was found to be suitable for a community college such as TOCC. The PI instructed the TOCC educator and helped developing a corresponding curriculum covering the Lotka-Volterra predator-prey model. The PI also participated in undergraduate training through the NSF REU program. and gave several colloquium and special seminar talks (including talks at German universities). The colloquium he gave at his home institution, titled "Help, there is a zebra in the quantum fluid!",  is available online.
